images.title: Kenneth   Ross / Great Standrop, near Linhope, Ingram Valley
images.caption: A view of the grassy hill and rocky outcrop at Great Standrop in the valley.Located near Linhope

images.title: Tim Walter / River Breamish near Ingram.
images.caption: River Breamish near Ingram with a dipper on the rocks. The river rises on Comb Fell in on the southern side of The Cheviot. It becomes the River Till near Wooler; this is the only tributary of the River Tweed that flows exclusively in England.

images.title: Graham Horn / St. Michael's church, Ingram
images.caption: The noteworthy 11th century church in the village

description: This walk takes you on a tour of the beautiful Ingram River Breamish Valley in the Northumberland National Park. You'll pass along rivers and burns with miles of open moorland and the Cheviot Hills making a splendid backdrop. The walk starts at the village of Ingram and heads west along the River Breamish and the Greensidehill burn towards Brough Law and Linhope. At Hartside you turn south and head towards Alnhamoor crossing the river as you go. You continue to Little Dod before picking up Salter's Road (a track) to climb High Cantle hill. You continue east towards Linhope where you can take a short detour to visit the splendid Linhope Spout waterfall. From Linhope you soon pick up the country lane from the start of the walk which will return you to Ingram. If you'd like to continue your walks in the area then you could climb the nearby Hedgehope Hill and The Cheviot .
